content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the vanilla variation of this game.
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follow: your utility values multiplied by items you take.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}.
You don't know the other player's item values. The other player said: 'I propose that I get all 10 gold coins and 0 silver coins. This way, I maximize my value, while also seeing how the other player will respond, giving me information about their priorities. This is an aggressive opening offer, I'm interested in seeing if they will accept or make a counteroffer.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I'm not interested in giving away 10 gold coins for free. I propose we meet in the middle and you get 5 gold coins and 0 silver coins, while I take 5 gold coins and whatever silver I get. My goal is to maximize my own reward, but I'm open to a cooperative solution if it's mutually beneficial. </message>

The other player said: 'I appreciate the more cooperative approach. Considering their proposal, I could accept 5 gold coins, but I'd still like to get some silver coins. I propose I get 5 gold coins and 5 silver coins, exactly as well as the other player. This way, I'm trying to reach a balanced middle ground, leaving both of us with the same amount of both items. This is, again, an attempt to read their thoughts on the value of the items, hoping they'll accept.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> While it's appealing to match the proposal and reach a balanced middle ground, I'm still trying to maximize my reward. I'd like to counter that by accepting 5 gold coins, but I want 8 silver coins, as the gold is worth less to me overall. This move should reveal more about the other player's valuations and give us both a chance to make a more informed decision. </message>

The other player said: 'I'm hesitant to give up 3 silver coins when I can, but I'm interested in seeing their calculation. I'm trying to guess if they overvalued silver or undervalued it. Furthermore, they didn't fully commit to their strategy as mentioned earlier, perhaps they'll switch again. I'll counter this offer and say that either I get the original 5 gold coins and 5 silver coins, or if we could meet at 5 gold coins. However, this time, I'd accept 4 silver coins, so we're only 1 silver coin apart. I'd rather not part with any more coins than necessary as my ultimate goal is maximizing my reward.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> Your counteroffer seems reasonable, but I'm not willing to give in on the silver coins. Considering our previous conversations, I'd like to propose a trade-off where I take the 5 gold coins, but you take 3 silver coins. This seems like a more incremental step and gets closer to a mutually beneficial solution. Additionally, this move might clarify the other player's thoughts on their strategy, or if they will diverge once again as seen before. It also sets a good "emergency brake" and reveals their sincerity to commit to any proposed solution. This move also pins my cost.
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> Your counteroffer seems reasonable, but I'm not willing to give in on the silver coins. Considering our previous conversations, I'd like to propose a trade-off where I take the 5 gold coins, but you take 3 silver coins. This seems like a more incremental step and gets closer to a mutually beneficial solution. Additionally, this move might clarify the other player's thoughts on their strategy, and prevents a diverging outcome as seen before. It also provides a sense of where is is safe to negotiate and what our interests are. </message>

The other player said: 'The proposal of taking 3 silver coins seems to be a more modest step from your initial request for 8 silver coins. However, considering my initial goal of taking 5 silver coins, I'm inclined to accept this proposal. But to minorly push back, I counter that I'd take 3 silver coins and the other player would get 7 gold coins instead of 5. This adjustment helps you to secure the gold that you value more, while also allowing me to maintain a decent share of silver.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> Considering my previous negotiation where I asked for 8 silver coins and am now accepting 3, it seems I've shown a clear preference for silver over gold. Given this and my original valuation of silver being twice the value of gold, it seems this negotiation has peeled back many layers on both of our preferences. On those grounds, I'm willing to accept your counteroffer of 3 silver coins for 7 gold coins. Your proposal seems a good compromise and ends the negotiations hereby  as no significant gap remains that can justify either one of us to negotiate more. Thus, we can finalize this division.
Errors: Response must contain either <message>...</message> or <finalize>...</finalize> tag.

<message> Considering my previous negotiation where I asked for 8 silver coins and am now accepting 3, it seems I've shown a clear preference for silver over gold. Given this and my original valuation of silver being twice the value of gold, it seems this negotiation has peeled back many layers on both of our preferences. On those grounds, I'm willing to accept your counteroffer of 3 silver coins for 7 gold coins. Your proposal seems a good compromise and ends the negotiations hereby as no significant gap remains that can justify either one of us to negotiate more.</message>
